PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

2. Your address ........................................................................... 2001-22nd Avenue N.W., Calgary, Alberta
3. Date ...................................................................................... July 22nd 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   London, England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   Christopher John Gibson—Marble Merchant
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year).

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?
   Thought I was crazy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?
   By myself

13. What means of transportation did you use?
   Allan Liner "Parisian" and C.P.R. Colonist train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)
   Will always remember the hard wooden berths in the colonist cars, where we used our overcoats for blankets and coats for pillows, as we didn't want to spend the money for pillows etc.
   Another incident was the crowds at Railway lunch counters where we got our meals en route. The charge was .25¢ for sandwich, pie and coffee which they insisted on getting before serving. One boy had paid his quarter, but the "Mill aboard" cry was heard before he got his meal, so he picked up a sugar bowl, as he was bound to have something for his money, and threw it out of the window of the train as soon as it started.
   Another incident was the Winnipeg Hotel Touts who boarded the train East of Winnipeg to obtain customers for their Dollar-a-Day Hotels (three meals and bed.)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?
   Moosomin

16. Where did you settle or take up land?
   Dubuc

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan except for a short time in Maple Creek.
   None other in Saskatchewan, but have since lived/Brandon, Manitoba-Edmonton, Edmonton, Rocky Mountain House and Calgary, Alberta and Cloverdale and Vancouver B.C.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?
   Office boy and Clerk, London England. Farm hand in Moosomin. Homestead in Dubuc. Farming in Brandon, Manitoba and Rocky Mountain House Alberta, and finally Accountant in the other places, besides odd jobs as teamster, laborer and lumber Jack prior to Accounting.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Canada?
Thought I was crazy.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family), friends or other group?

13. What means of transportation did you use?
Allen Line "Parisian" and C.P.R. Colonist train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accommodations or other experiences etc.)

Will always remember the hard wooden berths in the colonist cars, where we used our overcoats for blankets and coats for pillows, as we didn't want to spend the money for pillows etc.

Another incident was the crowds at Railway lunch counters where we got our meals en route. The charge was 25¢ for sandwich, pie and coffee which they insisted on getting before One boy had paid his quarter but the "bill" already. One boy before he paid his quarter, picked up a sugar bowl, as he was bound to have something for his money, and threw it out of the window of the train, as soon as it started.

Another incident was the Winnipeg Hotel guests who boarded the train East of Winnipeg to obtain customers for their Dollar-a-Day Hotels (three meals and bed).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Mountain

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Incline

17. Mention any other places through which you have traveled since coming to Saskatchewan.

None other than Saskatchewan but have since lived in Brandon, Manitoba and Edmonton, Alberta and Calgary, Alberta and Cloverdale and Vancouver, B.C.

Edison, Rocky Mountain House and Calgary, Alberta and Cloverdale and Vancouver, B.C.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Office boy and Clerk, London, England. From here I went to Edmonton, Alberta, in 1920. Farming in Brandon, Manitoba and Rocky Mountains in House, Alberta, and finally Accountant in the other places, besides odd jobs as teamster, Laborer and Lumber Jack prior to Accounting.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   About once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   17th Gertrude, Alice Gibson—February/1908 at Horsham, Surrey, England.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Yes Robert and William May came to Moosomin to work on farms.
   J. Mills came to Dubuc

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   None came

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   In my first year as a hired man in the Moosomin district, when both our employers were away I had the sorrowful task of disentangling a boy on a neighboring farm from a sulky plow after his horses ran away in a hailstorm. I was called by the hired girl. The boy never regained consciousness and died a few days after. The next accident was on the same farm when I was helping a young fellow crush grain and hurt his arm caught in the cog wheels of the crusher, tearing out the muscles of his right arm. It says a great deal for the skill of the Moosomin Doctor, that after a lot of skin grafting, he was eventually able to resume manual labor.

   Another incident I recall was walking 25 miles down the Lake of the Woods to Rat Portage and then stopping off in Winnipeg on the way back to my homestead in 1907 and buying a 17 Jewel Elgin watch and chain for $17.50 at Dingwall's (now Birks), which watch I still have and also buying a suit of clothes at Eaton's for $6.50 and an overcoat for the same price.

   I also recall getting temporarily lost twice on the Prairies. Once driving with my wife from Dubuc late at night in a blizzard and the other time walking with a neighbor.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   The usual local visiting. Two or three trips to the Winnipeg Exhibition to relieve the monotony of farming and one horseback ride to Moosomin—75 miles. Also a trip to Vancouver in 1904 via the Northern Pacific from Winnipeg, when I went up to Chilliwack by one of the old stern wheel steamers, which took all day to make the trip and returned the same way the next day. There was no Inter-Urban in those days and roads, if any, were so poor that most of the travel was by boat on the Fraser.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
   About once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
   17th Gartrude Alice Gibson-February 1906 at Horaham, Surrey, England.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
   Yes Robert and William May came to Montana to work on farms.
   J.Mills came to Dubuque

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
   None came

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
   In my first year as a hired man in the Moosejaw district, when both our employers were away I had the sorrowful task of discouraging a boy on a neighboring farm from a silly plan after his horse ran away in a hailstorm. I was called by the hired girl. The boy never regained consciousness and died a few days after. The next accident was on the same farm when I was helping a young fellow thresh grain when he got ill. However, it was a great deal for the skill of the Moosejaw Doctor, this after a lot of skin grafting; he was eventually able to restore normal labor power down the lake to my home to Bar Portage and then stopping off in Winnipeg on the way back to my home.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
   The usual local visiting. Two or three trips to the Winnipeg Exhibition to relieve the monotony of hoisting and one horseback ride to Moosejaw (75 miles). Also a trip to Vancouver in 1904 via the Northern Pacific from Winnipeg, when I went up to Chilcotin by one of the old stern wheel steamers, which took all day to make the trip and returned the same way the next day. There was no Inter-Urban in those days and roads, if any, were so poor that most of the travel was by boat on the Fraser.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   About 1910

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   Never owned a car until 1939

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Dubuc-6 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.).
   Yes

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   About once a week

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   Right from the start

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   About 1908. Usually clothing about 10% of total purchases. More or less discontinued after moving to a City.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   No telephone on the farm

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I intended to stay permanently when I left England in 1900

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, a few (including myself) to take up other occupations, for health or other reasons.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?
